content: In this section we review several aspects of human nutritional needs, and hence the needs of the agricultural system.

sections.name: Nutritional Needs
content: Humans need more than mere calorie count to survive. Following are estimates of needs by macronutrient, vitamin, and mineral.
-dietary_needs.jpg
Estimated macronutrient, vitamin, and mineral needs for an adult male, based on a 2200 calorie overall diet. Source: [nutrition_needs].

sections.name: Diet and Health
content: In general, Americans consume too much added sugar, sodium, and saturated fat, and not enough valuable minerals.
-dietary_needs2.jpg
!Source: [nutrition_needs].
Obesity, resulting primarily from eating too much food, is a growing problem.
-obesity.jpg
!Sources: CIA [obesity1] and World Health Organization [obesity2].
Additionally, 39% of the world's adults are considered overweight [obesity3]. Obesity is linked with 4.7 million deaths globally per year [obesity3], one of the leading causes.

Complicating efforts to address malnutrition are food allergies, which affect about 10% of American adults [food_allergy1]. About 90% of food allergic reactions can be attributed to the following: milk, eggs, peanuts, tree nuts, fish, shellfish, soy, and wheat [food_allergy2].

sections.name: Micronutrient Deficiency
content: Major nutrient deficiencies, their effects, and their pravalencies are as follows.
-diet_needs.py
!Sources: Biban and Lichiardopol [iodine_deficiency], Our World in Data [owid_micronutrient], and Roth et al. [vitamin_d].
About half of children around the world suffer from "hidden hunger", or some form of micronutrient deficiency.
-hidden_hunger.jpg
!Source: UNICEF [state_children].

Micronutrient defiency can be addressed, among other methods, through fortification: dietary supplements, food fortification (e.g. adding micronutrients to cereals and other foods), and biofortification (genetic engineering, such as adding Vitamin A to golden rice) [owid_micronutrient].
Salt Iodization

Because salt is commonly consumed and easy to fortify, iodization of salt is a preferred method to respon to iodine deficiency. The World Health Organization estimates that it costs 2 to 5 cents per person per year to iodize salt [salt_iodization].
